title: Quiz 4: Protozoa & Virology
description: Assess your understanding of protozoan classification, symbiotic relationships, and the unique characteristics and life cycles of viruses.

questions.question: Match the type of symbiosis with its definition:

pairs.right: One organism benefits, the host is harmed
One benefits, the other is neither harmed nor benefits

questions.explanation: Parasitism hurts the host; Commensalism is neutral for one; Mutualism helps both.

questions.question: Which subphylum of Sarcomastigophora uses 'pseudopodia' (false feet) for locomotion?
questions.explanation: Sarcodina (like Amoeba) use pseudopodia. Mastigophora use flagella.

questions.question: Viruses are described as ___BLANK___ intracellular parasites because they cannot reproduce outside a host cell.
questions.explanation: Obligate means they are restricted to a particular mode of life (intracellular replication).

questions.question: Order the steps of the viral life cycle:
questions.explanation: Virus attaches -> enters -> makes copies -> builds new viruses -> exits.

questions.question: Which of the following are basic forms/shapes of viruses? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Complex, Naked, and Enveloped are viral forms. Bacilli is a bacterial shape.
questions.hint: One of these is a bacteria shape.

questions.question: Members of the Phylum Apicomplexa (like Plasmodium) are all parasites.
questions.explanation: Apicomplexans are obligate parasites, including the malaria parasite.

questions.question: In viral taxonomy, what suffix is used to denote a viral 'Family'?
questions.explanation: Viral families end in -viridae (e.g., Herpesviridae). Genera end in -virus.

questions.question: Ciliates (Phylum Ciliophora) typically possess two types of nuclei. Which one regulates daily metabolic activities?
questions.explanation: The Macronucleus controls metabolism (Macro = Big job). The Micronucleus is for reproduction.

questions.question: Which of the following describes a 'complex' virus?

options.text: A virus with a simple helical capsid
A virus with an outer lipid membrane
A bacteriophage with a head and tail structure
A virus containing both DNA and RNA

questions.explanation: Bacteriophages are classic complex viruses with head-tail morphology.
questions.hint: It looks like a lunar lander.

questions.question: Viruses can replicate independently outside of a host cell.
questions.explanation: Viruses are acellular and lack the machinery to replicate; they must hijack a host cell.
questions.hint: Are they 'alive' on a table surface?
